I know this is an old video, but interestingly enough, this pattern follows the pattern of another problem a friend of mine introduced me to

The problem was, what is the maximum number of sections you can split a graph in d dimensions with n hyperplanes (a hyperplane being a region with one dimension lower than the dimension that it’s in, eg. A line in a 2d plane, a plane in 3D space)

This problem follows the pattern when d = 4, which I don’t completely understand, however looking at a spreadsheet of values for various n and d gives a couple of interesting patterns

It makes sense that, when splitting a dimension with hyperplanes, it follows the powers of 2 pattern until n > d, as up to n=d you can construct d perpendicular hyperplanes in dimension d (2 perpendicular lines in 2d space, 3 perpendicular planes in 3D space)

Ah! I almost got it in the right form this time, except for that I totally did not come upon this (6:00) approach to get the number of edges in the graph. Initially I went with approach that the number of vertices in the dual graph of the dual graph of the graph formed by the n lines will give "(the number of vertices of the circle) choose 4". However, it did not seem to work out.

And that about the Pascal's Triangle is mesmerizing. It arises due to the fact that C(0, x) for real x < 0, is equal to 0. So for n <= 5,
C(n, 2) + C(n, 4) + 1 = 2^n,
where C(x, y) represents "x choose y".

So, a circle w/ non-collinear points on the circumference will have a power of 2 sections when n is less than or equal to 5 * 2^x, where x is a natural number.
This is true because n = 5 satisfies all the numbers in the nth (5th) row of Pascal’s Triangle, n = 10 satisfies half of its row, & 20 will be a fourth. This pattern will continue because a power of 2 divided by a power of 2 is always a power of 2 (so long as the quotient is greater than or equal to 2).
I’ll leave it to you to find out how many sections a “power of 2 circle” will have for x (not n, since the video already demonstrates that!).

I used finite differences to build a formula for the sequence:

(1/24)x^4 - (1/4)x^3 + (23/24)x^2 - (3/4)x + 1

Put it in desmos.com and play around. You can see hypothetical situations such as fractional and negative numbers of lines. (What’s really interesting is that negative integers of lines always have positive integers of regions)

It is not necessary to use Euler's formula. Just count the number of line segments, which equals (n,2)+(n,4) because removing each point of (n,4) decreases the number of line segments by 1.  Next noting that removing each line segment decreases the number of regions by 1, we conclude the total number of regions is 1+(n,2)+(n,4).

There is another approach to solving this puzzle. Excuse my bad English...

If you add one point to the circle, and connect it with every other point, the line drawn from the new point to a point already on the circle, cuts some amount of lines. And for each line you cross, you add one segment, plus one, which you get even without crossing lines. Since each pair of points is actually a line / every point is connected to every other point, the amount of lines you cross is equal to the count of points left of the newly added line times the count of points right of the line. So when you draw a line from the new point to the i-th "old" point of a total of n "old" points, you add
i*(n-i)+1
segments. Now sum that up for every n, and you get
Σ(i=0; n; i*n+i²+1) = (n³+5n+6)/6
This is the number of segments added by the (n+2)th point. Why n+2? Because we assumed that there were n "old" points on the left and right side, plus one "old" point we are connecting to. To calculate the total number of segments added so far, we have to sum up this number for every point added so far, plus 1, because the circle has one segment without any points on it, which gives us
1+Σ(i=0; n; (n³+5n+6)/6) = (n⁴+2n³+11n²+34n+48)/24
But remember: this is for the (n+2)th point! If we replace n with n-2, we get:
(n⁴-6n³+23n²-18n+24)/24
as the finished formula for calculating the number of segments in a circle with n points on it.
If you don't believe me or those weird numbers look unreliable, try putting some values in this formula: it works!

I solved this before watching the video using a different approach. I counted the number of regions added with each new vertex and noticed a recurrence relation. This led to the following summation: 1+sum(sum(j*(i-j)+1,j=0...i),i=0...(n-2)) which simplifies to the polynomial (n^4 - 6*n^3 + 23*n^2 - 18*n+24)/24. I'm actually a bit surprised to get this result after watching this video since I would assume with all those binomial coefficients the solution would be on the order n! instead of n^4. I guess I shouldn't have been since nchoosek(n,4) is also on the order of n^4 :D

Adding to that, for n > 5, you have to subtract the number of vertices where 3 major lines intersect. So for that 6 dot figure where the lines converged into one vertice, you take the 1+15+15, and subtract one. For perfectly divided 7- figures, you would have to subtract up to 3, leaving 54.

I used induction and it's much more complicated in the sense of calculation.
Consider we add an n-th point. Suppose there are k new intersection points on the line segment connecting this point and an existing point. Then there will be (k+1) new regions.
On the other hand we have (n-1) such new line segments and (n-1)Choose3 new intersection points.
Thus we have (n-1)C3 + (n-1) new regions.
Now we have
A_1 = 1
A_n = A_(n-1) + (n-1)C3 + (n-1)
Take the sum and we'll arrive at the formula many already got in the earlier comments.

This is almost a couple years old now so I dunno if my comment will even be noted but at 4:23 when you discuss moving 2 edges and being able to create extra faces, it actually doesn't break the formula at all. If you treat a Vertex as a place where 2 or more lines meet, an Edge as the line travelling between 2 points, and a face as a space between a given set of Vertices and Edges

Then bending the 2 Edges you gain 2 faces, 2 vertices, and 4 edges so you have a net 0 change in the rest of the formula when you consider all the remaining vertices, edges and faces. Also if you consider that odd, 2 triangle and ellipse as a singular shape (ignoring the rest of the box) you have 6 vertices, 8 edges, and 4 faces (V - E + F [6 - 8 + 4 = 2])

(1+3+5+7+9+11) +
(1+4+7+10+13) +
(1+5+9+13)+
(1+6+11)+
(1+7)+
1 = 163
The total regions for a nonagon.

the "n choose m" notation has always been very confusing to me, i much prefer the factorial notation (n! - (n-m)!)/m!, though it ends up meaning the same thing.

it makes more sense to me because the factorial means "the total number of ways to pick N objects from a set of N objects", so (n!-(n-m)!)/m! means
the total number of ways to pick N objects from N total
minus
the number of ways to pick N-M objects when N-M objects are left
divided by
the number of ways to pick M objects from M objects

A little late to the 3B1B party, but I think this is my favorite of all your videos, 'cause not only did I get really invested in solving the problem, but I took a superficially completely different path that was actually really similar. As if you went 2 blocks east, 6 blocks south, and 2 block east, but I went 3 blocks east, 6 blocks south, and 1 block east. Algebra Ave had a lot more potholes and a lot less scenery than Combinatorics Ave, but I got there!

I got the idea to see how many sections each point added. The nth point will clearly add n-1 lines. It's pretty clear that each line will add a number of new sections equal to 1+the number of lines crossing it. After a bunch of doodling, I figured out that the number of crossings of each line is equal to the number of points on one side of it times the number of points on the other side of it (the two endpoints aren't on any side). An embarrassing number of off-by-one errors latter, I got this expressed as: for the line from the new point to the j-th point (with j starting from 0) counterclockwise from the new point, the number of crossings is j*((n-2)-j).

This gives me that f(n) = f(n-1) + Σ (j=0 --> n-2)(j*((n-2)-j)+1). I tried to do this combinatorically, but gave up and did it with algebra/the calculus of finite differences, which got me the correct answer! In a pretty ugly form, which I suspected had a pretty combinatoric method of expression--and it did! A truly enjoyable ride from start to finish, even with the arithmetic errors.

I solved the number of intersections in similar, but slightly differing way that I found extremely elegant and satisfying. I'll put it here.

Label the n points on the circle P(0), P(1), ..., P(n-1), and denote a line segment from X to Y as [X Y]. Then, we say [P(a) P(b)] intersects [P(c) P(d)] if 0 ≤ a ≤ c ≤ b ≤ d < n. Hence, if we can find the number of solutions (a, b, c, d) satisfying this inequality in terms of n, this is equal to the number of intersections on the circle. This is Σ_{0≤a≤c≤b≤d<n} 1 = Σ_{b≤d<n} Σ_{c≤b<d} Σ_{a≤c<d} Σ_{0≤a<c} 1 = (n to the 4 falling)/4! = (n)(n-1)(n-2)(n-3)/1·2·3·4.

Sorry I couldn't explain that last step in full, I would do so if I had the space here, it's based upon the second chapter of Knuth's Concrete Mathematics. These inequalities contained within Σ_{} are supposed to be underneath the sum, if that wasn't clear.

I'm at 8:21 and had to pause for a moment to ask these questions to formulate a hypothesis (that I haven't yet taken a minute to test myself):

So does this mean that where n (number of points) is a multiple of 10 (n = 10x), the number of regions (F) in a circle is a power of 2?
Perhaps this would follow a pattern where the power is itself a multiple of 4?
Thus, for x, n = 10x, F = 2^(4x)?
Would it be because we are adding, successively, 1/(2^x) of each row of the triangle?

I think I'm gonna sit down with a notebook after this video's over to check this myself...

EDIT
Well I just took the math in here and plugged it into a spreadsheet, and went as far as 200 points on a circle... The answers to all of my questions are a resounding NO. :P In fact, the difference between the number of regions and the nearest power of 2 varies pretty wildly, but with an odd pattern. Every once in a while, the difference is tremendously greater than the previous one, and each difference afterward is slightly less and less until the next upward jump.

I'm pretty sure this pattern has nothing to do with this whole problem, but it's a pattern in the data that I noticed nonetheless! It'd be neat if there's an explanation for it (but likely not).

Damn, why didn't I come up with the quadruplet thing for counting the intersection points? Instead, I thought of (starting from a circle with 3 outer points) adding a point to the graph with n-1 points and finding the number of intersections this new point creates with the previous ones. I found that that number is constant over each of the previous points, so the total number of intersections for each of the points is g*(n-1-g) where n is the number of points from the previous graph and g is the grade of separation around the circle between the point in question and the newly added point, starting at 0. If you take the sum from g=0 to n-1 of g*(n-1-g), you get the number of intersection points this new point adds to the graph. Because we want the total number of intersections in the graph, we have to add up all intersections that were introduced earlier (starting with a graph of size n=3). In other words, you take the sum from n=3 to p of the sum from g=0 to n-1 of g*(n-1-g) where p is the number of points in the graph we are looking for. This equals 1/24 * (x-3)(x-2)(x-1)x, which also leads to the correct solution. Of course, the quadruplet solution is way more elegant and simpler. Anyways, great animation and explanation as always :)
